On the Achievable Rate Regions for Interference Channels with Degraded Message Sets†

Jinhua Jiang and Yan Xin
† The work is supported by the National University of Singapore (NUS) under start-up grants R-263-000-314-101 and R-263-000-314-112 and by a NUS Research Scholarship. The correspondence author of the paper is Dr. Yan Xin (tel. no. +65 6516-5513 and fax no. +65 6779-1103). Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
National University of Singapore, Singapore 117576
Email: { jinhua.jiang, elexy }@nus.edu.sg
Abstract

The interference channel with degraded message sets (IC-DMS) refers to a communication model in which two senders attempt to communicate with their respective receivers simultaneously through a common medium, and one of the senders has complete and a priori (non-causal) knowledge about the message being transmitted by the other. A coding scheme that collectively has advantages of cooperative coding, collaborative coding, and dirty paper coding, is developed for such a channel. With resorting to this coding scheme, achievable rate regions of the IC-DMS in both discrete memoryless and Gaussian cases are derived, which, in general, include several previously known rate regions. Numerical examples for the Gaussian case demonstrate that in the high-interference-gain regime, the derived achievable rate regions offer considerable improvements over these existing results.

Index Terms:
Cognitive radio, cooperative communication, degrade message sets, dirty paper coding, Gel’fand-Pinsker coding, interference channels, superposition coding.

I Introduction

The interference channel with degraded message sets (IC-DMS) refers a communication model in which two senders attempt to communicate with their respective receivers simultaneously through a common medium, and one of the senders has complete and a priori (non-causal) knowledge about the message being transmitted by the other. Such a model generically characterizes some realistic communication scenarios taking place in cognitive radio channels [1, 2] or in wireless sensor networks over a correlated field [3, 4], which we illustrate in Figs. 1(a) and 1(b).

From an information-theoretic perspective, the IC-DMS have been investigated in [1, 4, 2, 3]. Specifically, several achievable rate results have been obtained in [1, 4, 2, 3], and the capacity regions for two special cases have been characterized in [4, 2, 3]. The main achievable rate region in [1] was obtained by incorporating the Gel’fand-Pinsker coding [5] into the well-known coding scheme applied to the interference channel (IC) [6, 7]. In this coding scheme, each of the two senders splits its message into two sub-messages, and allows its non-pairing receiver to decode one of the sub-messages. Knowing the two sub-messages and the corresponding codewords which sender 1 wishes to transmit, sender 2 applies the Gel’fand-Pinsker coding to encode its own sub-messages by treating the codewords of sender 1 as known interferences. It has been also shown in [1, Corollary 2] that, an improved achievable rate region can be attained by time-sharing between the early derived rate region and a so called fully-cooperative rate point achieved by letting sender 2 use all its power to transmit sender 1’ messages. A different coding scheme was adopted in [2] and [3], in which neither of the senders splits its message into two sub-messages, and receiver 2 does not decode any transmitted information from sender 1. Since sender 2 knows what sender 1 wishes to transmit, sender 2 is allowed to: 1) apply the Gel’fand-Pinsker coding to encode its own message; and 2) partially cooperate with sender 1 using superposition coding. It has been proven in [2, 3] that, this is the capacity-achieving scheme for the Gaussian IC-DMS in the low-interference-gain regime, in which the normalized link gain between sender 2 and receiver 1 is less than or equal to 111.

However, in practice, due to the mobility of the users or random distributions of the sensors, sender 2 may be geographically located near to receiver 1, as illustrated in Fig. 2. It is likely, in such a situation, that the Gaussian IC-DMS is in the high-interference-gain regime, in which the normalized link gain between sender 2 and receiver 1 is greater than 1. In fact, the findings in this paper reveal that the achievable rate region, which was proven to be the capacity region in the low-interference-gain regime in [2] and [3], is strictly non-optimal for the Gaussian IC-DMS in the high-interference-gain regime.

In this paper, we develop a new coding scheme for the IC-DMS to improve existing achievable rate regions. Our coding scheme differs from one proposed in [2, 3] in the way that, sender 2 splits its message into two sub-messages, and encodes both sub-messages using Gel’fand-Pinsker coding. Moreover, receiver 1 is required to jointly decode the message from sender 1 and one sub-message from sender 2. With this coding scheme, we derive our main achievable rate region for the discrete memoryless case. For comparison purpose, we compromise either the coding flexibility (fixing an auxiliary random variable as a constant), or the advantage of simultaneous decoding [7], to obtain two subregions of the main achievable rate region. The obtained subregions are shown to either include or be the same as the existing ones. We further extend the obtained regions from the discrete memoryless case to the Gaussian case, and show by numerical examples that our Gaussian achievable rate results strictly improve the existing ones in the high-interference-gain regime.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we introduce the channel model of the IC-DMS, and the related terminologies. In Section III, we present the main achievable result for the discrete memoryless case with a detailed proof. In Section IV, we derive two subregions of the main achievable rate region, and we show that the derived subregions include several existing results as special cases. Lastly, in Section V, we extend our rate regions from the discrete memoryless case to the Gaussian case, and compare them with the existing results.

Notations: Random variables and their realizations are denoted by upper case letters and lower case letters respectively, e.g., X𝑋X and x𝑥x. Bold lower (upper) case letters are used to denote vectors (matrices), e.g., 𝐱𝐱\mathbf{x} and 𝚺𝚺\mathbf{\Sigma}. Calligraphic fonts are used to denote sets, e.g., 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} and ℛℛ\mathcal{R}.

II The Channel Model

Consider the IC-DMS (also termed as the genie-aided cognitive radio channel in [1]) depicted in Fig. 3, in which sender 1 wishes to transmit a message (or message index), w1∈ℳ1:={1,…,M1}subscript𝑤1subscriptℳ1assign1…subscript𝑀1w_{1}\in\mathcal{M}_{1}:=\{1,...,M_{1}\}, to receiver 1 and sender 2 wishes to transmit its message, w2∈ℳ2:={1,…,M2}subscript𝑤2subscriptℳ2assign1…subscript𝑀2w_{2}\in\mathcal{M}_{2}:=\{1,...,M_{2}\}, to receiver 2. Typically, this discrete memoryless IC-DMS is described by a tuple (𝒳1,𝒳2,𝒴1,𝒴2,p​(y1,y2|x1,x2))subscript𝒳1subscript𝒳2subscript𝒴1subscript𝒴2𝑝subscript𝑦1conditionalsubscript𝑦2subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2(\mathcal{X}_{1},\mathcal{X}_{2},\mathcal{Y}_{1},\mathcal{Y}_{2},p(y_{1},y_{2}|x_{1},x_{2})), where 𝒳1subscript𝒳1\mathcal{X}_{1} and 𝒳2subscript𝒳2\mathcal{X}_{2} are the channel input alphabets, 𝒴1subscript𝒴1\mathcal{Y}_{1} and 𝒴2subscript𝒴2\mathcal{Y}_{2} are the channel output alphabets, and p​(y1,y2|x1,x2)𝑝subscript𝑦1conditionalsubscript𝑦2subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2p(y_{1},y_{2}|x_{1},x_{2}) denotes the conditional probability of (y1,y2)∈𝒴1×𝒴2subscript𝑦1subscript𝑦2subscript𝒴1subscript𝒴2(y_{1},y_{2})\in\mathcal{Y}_{1}\times\mathcal{Y}_{2} given (x1,x2)∈𝒳1×𝒳2subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2subscript𝒳1subscript𝒳2(x_{1},x_{2})\in\mathcal{X}_{1}\times\mathcal{X}_{2}. The channel is discrete memoryless in the sense that

p​(y1,t,y2,t|x1,t,x2,t,x1,t−1,x2,t−1,…)=p​(y1,t,y2,t|x1,t,x2,t),𝑝subscript𝑦1𝑡conditionalsubscript𝑦2𝑡subscript𝑥1𝑡subscript𝑥2𝑡subscript𝑥1𝑡1subscript𝑥2𝑡1…𝑝subscript𝑦1𝑡conditionalsubscript𝑦2𝑡subscript𝑥1𝑡subscript𝑥2𝑡\displaystyle p(y_{1,t},y_{2,t}|x_{1,t},x_{2,t},x_{1,{t-1}},x_{2,{t-1}},...)=p(y_{1,t},y_{2,t}|x_{1,t},x_{2,t}), (1)

for every discrete time instant t𝑡t in a synchronous transmission. In terms of the channel input-output relationship, the IC-DMS is the same as the IC. However, in the IC-DMS, sender 2 is able to noncausally obtain the knowledge of the message w1subscript𝑤1w_{1}, which will be transmitted from sender 1. This is the key difference between the IC-DMS and IC in terms of the information flow. We next present the following standard definitions with regard to the existence of codes and achievable rates for the discrete memoryless IC-DMS channel.

Definition 1

An (M1,M2,n,Pe)subscript𝑀1subscript𝑀2𝑛subscript𝑃𝑒(M_{1},M_{2},n,P_{e}) code exists for the discrete memoryless IC-DMS, if and only if there exist two encoding functions

and two decoding functions

such that max⁡{Pe,1(n),Pe,2(n)}≤Pesuperscriptsubscript𝑃𝑒1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑒2𝑛subscript𝑃𝑒\max\{P_{e,1}^{(n)},P_{e,2}^{(n)}\}\leq P_{e}, where Pe,1(n)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑒1𝑛P_{e,1}^{(n)} and Pe,2(n)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑒2𝑛P_{e,2}^{(n)} denote the respective average probabilities of error at decoders 111 and 222, and are computed as

Pe,1(n)=1M1​M2​∑w1​w2p​(w^1≠w1|(w1,w2)​ were sent),subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝑛𝑒11subscript𝑀1subscript𝑀2subscriptsubscript𝑤1subscript𝑤2𝑝subscript^𝑤1conditionalsubscript𝑤1subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤2 were sent\displaystyle P^{(n)}_{e,1}=\frac{1}{M_{1}M_{2}}\sum_{w_{1}w_{2}}p(\hat{w}_{1}\neq w_{1}|(w_{1},w_{2})\text{~{}were~{}sent}),

Definition 2

A non-negative rate pair (R1,R2)subscript𝑅1subscript𝑅2(R_{1},R_{2}) is achievable for the IC-DMS, if for any given 0<Pe<10subscript𝑃𝑒10<P_{e}<1 and any sufficiently large n𝑛n, there exists a (2n​R1,2n​R2,n,Pe)superscript2𝑛subscript𝑅1superscript2𝑛subscript𝑅2𝑛subscript𝑃𝑒(2^{nR_{1}},2^{nR_{2}},n,P_{e}) code for the channel. The capacity region of the IC-DMS is the set of all the achievable rate pairs for the channel, and an achievable rate region is a subset of the capacity region.

It should be noted that from an information-theoretic standpoint, the IC can not be simply treated as a special case of the IC-DMS in the sense that the capacity region of the IC-DMS, if any, does not imply a capacity region of the IC.

Let 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} denote the capacity region of the discrete memoryless IC-DMS, and let

ℛ=⋃p​(⋅)∈𝒫ℛ​(p).ℛsubscript𝑝⋅𝒫ℛ𝑝\mathcal{R}=\bigcup_{p(\cdot)\in\mathcal{P}}\mathcal{R}(p).
Theorem 1

The region ℛℛ\mathcal{R} is an achievable rate region for the discrete memoryless IC-DMS, i.e., ℛ⊆𝒞ℛ𝒞\mathcal{R}\subseteq\mathcal{C}.

Proof:

Before presenting the proof of Theorem 1, we state the following lemma as it will be frequently used in the proof.

Lemma 1 ([8, Theorem 14.2.3])

Let Aϵ(n)subscriptsuperscript𝐴𝑛italic-ϵA^{(n)}_{\epsilon} denote the typical set for the probability mass distribution p​(s1,s2,s3)𝑝subscript𝑠1subscript𝑠2subscript𝑠3p(s_{1},s_{2},s_{3}), and let P​(𝐒1′=𝐬1,𝐒2′=𝐬2,𝐒3′=𝐬3)=∏i=1np​(s1​i|s3​i)​p​(s2​i|s3​i)​p​(s3​i)𝑃formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐒1′subscript𝐬1formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐒2′subscript𝐬2superscriptsubscript𝐒3′subscript𝐬3superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑛𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑠1𝑖subscript𝑠3𝑖𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑠2𝑖subscript𝑠3𝑖𝑝subscript𝑠3𝑖P({\mathbf{S}}_{1}^{\prime}={\mathbf{s}}_{1},{\mathbf{S}}_{2}^{\prime}={\mathbf{s}}_{2},{\mathbf{S}}_{3}^{\prime}={\mathbf{s}}_{3})=\prod_{i=1}^{n}p(s_{1i}|s_{3i})p(s_{2i}|s_{3i})p(s_{3i}), then P​{(𝐒1′,𝐒2′,𝐒3′)∈Aϵ(n)}≐2−n​(I​(S1′;S2′|S3′)±6​ϵ)approaches-limit𝑃superscriptsubscript𝐒1′superscriptsubscript𝐒2′superscriptsubscript𝐒3′subscriptsuperscript𝐴𝑛italic-ϵsuperscript2𝑛plus-or-minus𝐼subscriptsuperscript𝑆′1conditionalsubscriptsuperscript𝑆′2subscriptsuperscript𝑆′36italic-ϵP\{({\mathbf{S}}_{1}^{\prime},{\mathbf{S}}_{2}^{\prime},{\mathbf{S}}_{3}^{\prime})\in A^{(n)}_{\epsilon}\}\doteq 2^{-n(I(S^{\prime}_{1};S^{\prime}_{2}|S^{\prime}_{3})\pm 6\epsilon)}.

To prove this theorem we apply the notion of the asymptotic equipartition property (APE) [8]. Our coding scheme is mainly based on the arguments of superposition coding [9] and Gel’fand-Pinsker coding [5]. Specifically, sender 1 independently encodes its message w1subscript𝑤1w_{1} as a whole; while sender 2 needs split its message into two parts, i.e., w2=(w21,w22)subscript𝑤2subscript𝑤21subscript𝑤22w_{2}=(w_{21},w_{22}), and encode them separately. Both w21subscript𝑤21w_{21} and w22subscript𝑤22w_{22} are encoded using the Gel’fand-Pinsker approach, but they are processed differently at the receivers. The message w22subscript𝑤22w_{22} will be decoded by receiver 2 only, while w21subscript𝑤21w_{21} will be decoded by both receivers. Moreover, knowing the message and codeword which sender 1 is going to transmit, sender 2 not only can apply Gel’fand-Pinsker coding to deal with the known interference, but also can cooperate with sender 1 to transmit w1subscript𝑤1w_{1} using superposition coding. Let R21subscript𝑅21R_{21} and R22subscript𝑅22R_{22} denote the rates of w21subscript𝑤21w_{21} and w22subscript𝑤22w_{22} respectively, i.e., w21∈{1,…,2n​R21}subscript𝑤211…superscript2𝑛subscript𝑅21w_{21}\in\{1,\ldots,2^{nR_{21}}\} and w22∈{1,…,2n​R22}subscript𝑤221…superscript2𝑛subscript𝑅22w_{22}\in\{1,\ldots,2^{nR_{22}}\}. If receiver 1 can decode w1subscript𝑤1w_{1} and receiver 2 can decode both w21subscript𝑤21w_{21} and w22subscript𝑤22w_{22} with vanishing probabilities of error, then (R1,R21+R22)subscript𝑅1subscript𝑅21subscript𝑅22(R_{1},R_{21}+R_{22}) is an achievable rate pair for the IC-DMS.

To prove that the entire region ℛℛ\mathcal{R} is achievable for the channel, it is sufficient to prove that ℛ​(p)ℛ𝑝\mathcal{R}(p) is achievable for a fixed joint probability distribution p​(⋅)∈𝒫𝑝⋅𝒫p(\cdot)\in\mathcal{P}.

III-A Random Codebook Generation

Consider a fixed joint distribution p​(⋅)∈𝒫𝑝⋅𝒫p(\cdot)\in\mathcal{P}, and a random time-sharing codeword 𝐪𝐪{\mathbf{q}} of length n𝑛n, which is given to both senders and receivers. The codeword 𝐪𝐪{\mathbf{q}} is assumed to be generated according to ∏i=1np​(qi)subscriptsuperscriptproduct𝑛𝑖1𝑝subscript𝑞𝑖\prod^{n}_{i=1}p(q_{i}).

The entire codebook is revealed to both senders and receivers.

III-B Encoding and Transmission

We assume that the senders want to transmit a message vector (w1,w21,w22)=(j,k1,k2)subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤21subscript𝑤22𝑗subscript𝑘1subscript𝑘2(w_{1},w_{21},w_{22})=(j,k_{1},k_{2}). Sender 1 simply encodes the message as codeword 𝐱1​(j)subscript𝐱1𝑗{\mathbf{x}}_{1}(j) and sends the codeword with n𝑛n channel uses. Sender 2 will first need to look for a codeword 𝐮​(l^1)𝐮subscript^𝑙1{\mathbf{u}}(\hat{l}_{1}) in bin k1subscript𝑘1k_{1} such that (𝐮​(l^1),𝐰​(j),𝐪)∈Aϵ(n)𝐮subscript^𝑙1𝐰𝑗𝐪superscriptsubscript𝐴italic-ϵ𝑛({\mathbf{u}}(\hat{l}_{1}),{\mathbf{w}}(j),{\mathbf{q}})\in A_{\epsilon}^{(n)}, and a codeword 𝐯​(l^2)𝐯subscript^𝑙2{\mathbf{v}}(\hat{l}_{2}) in bin k2subscript𝑘2k_{2} such that (𝐯​(l^2),𝐰​(j),𝐪)∈Aϵ(n)𝐯subscript^𝑙2𝐰𝑗𝐪superscriptsubscript𝐴italic-ϵ𝑛({\mathbf{v}}(\hat{l}_{2}),{\mathbf{w}}(j),{\mathbf{q}})\in A_{\epsilon}^{(n)}. If sender 2 fails to do so, it will randomly pick a codeword 𝐮​(l^1)𝐮subscript^𝑙1{\mathbf{u}}(\hat{l}_{1}) from bin k1subscript𝑘1k_{1} or a codeword 𝐯​(l^2)𝐯subscript^𝑙2{\mathbf{v}}(\hat{l}_{2}) from bin k2subscript𝑘2k_{2}. Sender 2 then transmits codeword 𝐱2​(l^1,l^2,j)subscript𝐱2subscript^𝑙1subscript^𝑙2𝑗{\mathbf{x}}_{2}(\hat{l}_{1},\hat{l}_{2},j) through n𝑛n channel uses. We further assume that the transmissions are perfectly synchronized.

III-C Decoding

Receiver 1 first looks for all the index pairs (j^,l^^1)^𝑗subscript^^𝑙1(\hat{j},\hat{\hat{l}}_{1}) such that (𝐰​(j^),𝐮​(l^^1),𝐲1,𝐪)∈Aϵ(n)𝐰^𝑗𝐮subscript^^𝑙1subscript𝐲1𝐪superscriptsubscript𝐴italic-ϵ𝑛({\mathbf{w}}(\hat{j}),{\mathbf{u}}(\hat{\hat{l}}_{1}),{\mathbf{y}}_{1},{\mathbf{q}})\in A_{\epsilon}^{(n)}. If j^^𝑗\hat{j} in all the index pairs found are the same, receiver 1 determines w1=j^subscript𝑤1^𝑗w_{1}=\hat{j}, otherwise declares an error.

Receiver 2 will first look for all index pairs (l^¯1,l^^2)subscript¯^𝑙1subscript^^𝑙2(\bar{\hat{l}}_{1},\hat{\hat{l}}_{2}) such that (𝐮​(l^¯1),𝐯​(l^^2),𝐲2,𝐪)∈Aϵ(n)𝐮subscript¯^𝑙1𝐯subscript^^𝑙2subscript𝐲2𝐪superscriptsubscript𝐴italic-ϵ𝑛({\mathbf{u}}(\bar{\hat{l}}_{1}),{\mathbf{v}}(\hat{\hat{l}}_{2}),{\mathbf{y}}_{2},{\mathbf{q}})\in A_{\epsilon}^{(n)}. If l^¯1subscript¯^𝑙1\bar{\hat{l}}_{1} in all the index pairs found are indices of codewords 𝐮​(l^¯1)𝐮subscript¯^𝑙1{\mathbf{u}}(\bar{\hat{l}}_{1}) from the same bin with index k^1subscript^𝑘1\hat{k}_{1}, and l^^2subscript^^𝑙2\hat{\hat{l}}_{2} in all the index pairs found are indices of codewords 𝐯​(l^^2)𝐯subscript^^𝑙2{\mathbf{v}}(\hat{\hat{l}}_{2}) from the same bin with index k^2subscript^𝑘2\hat{k}_{2}, then receiver 2 will decode that (w21,w22)=(k^1,k^2)subscript𝑤21subscript𝑤22subscript^𝑘1subscript^𝑘2(w_{21},w_{22})=(\hat{k}_{1},\hat{k}_{2}) were transmitted; otherwise, an error is declared.

III-D Evaluation of Probability of Error

We now derive upper bounds for the probabilities of the respective error events, which may happen during the encoding and decoding process. Due to the symmetry of the codebook generation and encoding processing, the probability of error is not codeword dependent. Without loss of generality, we assume that (w1,w21,w22)=(1,1,1)subscript𝑤1subscript𝑤21subscript𝑤22111(w_{1},w_{21},w_{22})=(1,1,1) were encoded and transmitted. We next define the following three types of events:

[Evaluation of Pe​(dec1)subscript𝑃𝑒dec1P_{e}(\text{dec1})] An error is made if 1) E˙1,l^1csubscriptsuperscript˙𝐸𝑐1subscript^𝑙1\dot{E}^{c}_{1,\hat{l}_{1}} happens, and/or 2) there exists some j^≠1^𝑗1\hat{j}\neq 1 such that E˙j^,l^^1subscript˙𝐸^𝑗subscript^^𝑙1\dot{E}_{\hat{j},\hat{\hat{l}}_{1}} happens. (14)

To ensure that R1subscript𝑅1R_{1}, R21subscript𝑅21R_{21} and R22subscript𝑅22R_{22} are non-negative, we enforce four additional constraints (6)–(9). Therefore, the rate region ℛ​(p)ℛ𝑝\mathcal{R}(p) is achievable for a fixed joint probability distribution p​(⋅)∈𝒫𝑝⋅𝒫p(\cdot)\in\mathcal{P}, and Theorem 1 follows. ∎

Remark 1

The proposed coding scheme exploits three coding methods to achieve any rate pair in the rate region, ℛℛ\mathcal{R}. The first method is cooperation that is realized by the superposition relationship between 𝐰𝐰{\mathbf{w}} and 𝐱2subscript𝐱2{\mathbf{x}}_{2} through p​(x2|u~2,v~2,w,q)𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥2subscript~𝑢2subscript~𝑣2𝑤𝑞p(x_{2}|\tilde{u}_{2},\tilde{v}_{2},w,q). The second is collaboration, by which we mean that sender 2 separates its own message into two parts, i.e., w2=(w21,w22)subscript𝑤2subscript𝑤21subscript𝑤22w_{2}=(w_{21},w_{22}), and encodes w21subscript𝑤21w_{21} at a possibly low rate such that receiver 1 can decode it. By doing so, the effective interference caused by the signals carrying the sender 2’s information may be reduced. The third is Gel’fand-Pinsker coding, which we apply to encode both messages, w21subscript𝑤21w_{21} and w22subscript𝑤22w_{22}, from sender 2 by treating the codeword 𝐰𝐰{\mathbf{w}} as known interference. This perhaps allows receiver 2 to be able to decode the messages from sender 2 at the same rate as if the interference caused by sender 1 was not present [12].

IV Relating with Existing Rate Regions

In this section, we will show that Theorem 1 includes the achievable rate regions in [2, 3]. To demonstrate it, we compromise the advantages of the coding scheme developed in Section III to obtain the following subregions of ℛℛ\mathcal{R}.

Theorem 2

The rate region ℛsimsubscriptℛsim\mathcal{R}_{\text{sim}} is achievable for the discrete memoryless IC-DMS, i.e., ℛsim⊆ℛ⊆𝒞subscriptℛsimℛ𝒞\mathcal{R}_{\text{sim}}\subseteq\mathcal{R}\subseteq\mathcal{C}.

Proof:

The proof can be devised from the proof of Theorem 1 by customizing the original coding scheme for the new joint distribution (30). We change the encoding and decoding method for the message w21subscript𝑤21w_{21} (corresponding to U𝑈U), i.e., the Gel’fand-Pinsker coding used in the proof of Theorem 1 was replaced by the conventional random coding. Specifically, we generate 2n​R21superscript2𝑛subscript𝑅212^{nR_{21}} independent codewords 𝐮​(k1)𝐮subscript𝑘1{\mathbf{u}}(k_{1}), k1∈{1,…,2n​R21}subscript𝑘11…superscript2𝑛subscript𝑅21k_{1}\in\{1,\ldots,2^{nR_{21}}\}, according to ∏i=1np​(ui|qi)subscriptsuperscriptproduct𝑛𝑖1𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑞𝑖\prod^{n}_{i=1}p(u_{i}|q_{i}). The encoding and decoding are then adapted to the new codebook accordingly. Evaluating the probability of error in the same way as was done in the proof of Theorem 1, we obtain

R~22−R22≥I​(V;W|Q);subscript~𝑅22subscript𝑅22𝐼𝑉conditional𝑊𝑄\displaystyle\tilde{R}_{22}-R_{22}\geq I(V;W|Q); (35)
R1≤I​(W;Y1|U​Q),subscript𝑅1𝐼𝑊conditionalsubscript𝑌1𝑈𝑄\displaystyle R_{1}\leq I(W;Y_{1}|UQ), (36)
R1+R21≤I​(W​U;Y1|Q);subscript𝑅1subscript𝑅21𝐼𝑊𝑈conditionalsubscript𝑌1𝑄\displaystyle R_{1}+R_{21}\leq I(WU;Y_{1}|Q); (37)
R21≤I​(U;Y2|V​Q),subscript𝑅21𝐼𝑈conditionalsubscript𝑌2𝑉𝑄\displaystyle R_{21}\leq I(U;Y_{2}|VQ), (38)
R~22≤I​(V;Y2|U​Q),subscript~𝑅22𝐼𝑉conditionalsubscript𝑌2𝑈𝑄\displaystyle\tilde{R}_{22}\leq I(V;Y_{2}|UQ), (39)
R21+R~22≤I​(U​V;Y2|Q).subscript𝑅21subscript~𝑅22𝐼𝑈𝑉conditionalsubscript𝑌2𝑄\displaystyle R_{21}+\tilde{R}_{22}\leq I(UV;Y_{2}|Q). (40)

Again, we choose R~22−R22=I​(V;W|Q)subscript~𝑅22subscript𝑅22𝐼𝑉conditional𝑊𝑄\tilde{R}_{22}-R_{22}=I(V;W|Q) in (35), and then substitute R~22subscript~𝑅22\tilde{R}_{22} with R22+I​(V;Y2|U​Q)subscript𝑅22𝐼𝑉conditionalsubscript𝑌2𝑈𝑄R_{22}+I(V;Y_{2}|UQ) as well as R21subscript𝑅21R_{21} with R2−R22subscript𝑅2subscript𝑅22R_{2}-R_{22} in the group of (36)–(40). By applying Fourier-Motzkin elimination on the resulting inequalities to remove R22subscript𝑅22R_{22}, and adding the constraints that ensure the respective rates R1subscript𝑅1R_{1}, R21subscript𝑅21R_{21} and R22subscript𝑅22R_{22} to be non-negative, we obtain (31)–(34). Therefore, the region Rsim​(p)subscript𝑅sim𝑝R_{\text{sim}}(p) is achievable for a given p​(⋅)∈𝒫∗𝑝⋅superscript𝒫p(\cdot)\in\mathcal{P}^{*}, and the theorem follows. ∎

Note that simultaneous decoding (simultaneous joint typicality) is applied at both decoders. The advantage of simultaneous decoding over successive decoding is well demonstrated on the IC by Han and Kobayashi in [7]. We next modify the coding scheme by applying successive decoding instead of simultaneous decoding at both decoders to derive a subregion of ℛsimsubscriptℛsim\mathcal{R}_{\text{sim}}.

IV-B A Subregion of ℛsimsubscriptℛsim\mathcal{R}_{\text{sim}}

Let ℛsuc​(p)subscriptℛsuc𝑝\mathcal{R}_{\text{suc}}(p) denote the set of all achievable rate pairs (R1,R2)subscript𝑅1subscript𝑅2(R_{1},R_{2}) such that

R1≤I​(W;Y1|U​Q),subscript𝑅1𝐼𝑊conditionalsubscript𝑌1𝑈𝑄\displaystyle R_{1}\leq I(W;Y_{1}|UQ), (41)
R2≤min⁡{I​(U;Y1|Q),I​(U;Y2|Q)}+I​(V;Y2|U​Q)−I​(V;W|Q);subscript𝑅2𝐼𝑈conditionalsubscript𝑌1𝑄𝐼𝑈conditionalsubscript𝑌2𝑄𝐼𝑉conditionalsubscript𝑌2𝑈𝑄𝐼𝑉conditional𝑊𝑄\displaystyle R_{2}\leq\min\{I(U;Y_{1}|Q),I(U;Y_{2}|Q)\}+I(V;Y_{2}|UQ)-I(V;W|Q); (42)
0≤I​(V;Y1|U​Q)−I​(V;W|Q),0𝐼𝑉conditionalsubscript𝑌1𝑈𝑄𝐼𝑉conditional𝑊𝑄\displaystyle 0\leq I(V;Y_{1}|UQ)-I(V;W|Q), (43)

for a fixed joint probability distribution p​(⋅)∈𝒫∗𝑝⋅superscript𝒫p(\cdot)\in\mathcal{P}^{*}. Define

ℛsuc=⋃p​(⋅)∈𝒫∗ℛsuc​(p).subscriptℛsucsubscript𝑝⋅superscript𝒫subscriptℛsuc𝑝\displaystyle\mathcal{R}_{\text{suc}}=\bigcup_{p(\cdot)\in\mathcal{P}^{*}}\mathcal{R}_{\text{suc}}(p).
Theorem 3

The rate region ℛsucsubscriptℛsuc\mathcal{R}_{\text{suc}} is achievable for the discrete memoryless IC-DMS, i.e., ℛsuc⊆ℛsim⊆ℛ⊆𝒞subscriptℛsucsubscriptℛsimℛ𝒞\mathcal{R}_{\text{suc}}\subseteq\mathcal{R}_{\text{sim}}\subseteq\mathcal{R}\subseteq\mathcal{C}.

Proof:

The codebook generation, encoding and transmission remain the same as those used to prove Theorem 2, whereas the decoding processes at both decoders are altered. Both decoders decode w21subscript𝑤21w_{21} first, and then decoder 1 decodes w1subscript𝑤1w_{1} and decoder 2 decodes w22subscript𝑤22w_{22} respectively. Then the following can easily be obtained

R~22−R22≥I​(V;W|Q),subscript~𝑅22subscript𝑅22𝐼𝑉conditional𝑊𝑄\displaystyle\tilde{R}_{22}-R_{22}\geq I(V;W|Q), (44)
R21≤I​(U;Y1|Q),subscript𝑅21𝐼𝑈conditionalsubscript𝑌1𝑄\displaystyle R_{21}\leq I(U;Y_{1}|Q), (45)
R1≤I​(W;Y1|U​Q),subscript𝑅1𝐼𝑊conditionalsubscript𝑌1𝑈𝑄\displaystyle R_{1}\leq I(W;Y_{1}|UQ), (46)
R21≤I​(U;Y2|Q),subscript𝑅21𝐼𝑈conditionalsubscript𝑌2𝑄\displaystyle R_{21}\leq I(U;Y_{2}|Q), (47)
R~22≤I​(V;Y2|U​Q).subscript~𝑅22𝐼𝑉conditionalsubscript𝑌2𝑈𝑄\displaystyle\tilde{R}_{22}\leq I(V;Y_{2}|UQ). (48)

From (44)–(48), it is straightforward to obtain (41)–(43). Therefore, the region ℛsuc​(p)subscriptℛsuc𝑝\mathcal{R}_{\text{suc}}(p) is achievable, and the theorem follows immediately. ∎

Remark 2

Note that (45) is only necessary when the successive decoding is applied. This is because every decoding step in a successive decoding scheme is expected to have a vanishing probability of error.

In what follows, we further specialize the subregion ℛsucsubscriptℛsuc\mathcal{R}_{\text{suc}} to obtain two more achievable rate regions ℛsp1subscriptℛsp1\mathcal{R}_{\text{sp1}} and ℛsp2subscriptℛsp2\mathcal{R}_{\text{sp2}}. Let 𝒫1∗subscriptsuperscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}^{*}_{1} denote the set of all joint probability density distributions p​(⋅)𝑝⋅p(\cdot) that factor in the form of

p​(q,w,x1,v,v~,x2,y1,y2)=p​(q)​p​(x1,w|q)​p​(v,v~|w,q)​p​(x2|v~,w,q)​p​(y1,y2|x1,x2).𝑝𝑞𝑤subscript𝑥1𝑣~𝑣subscript𝑥2subscript𝑦1subscript𝑦2𝑝𝑞𝑝subscript𝑥1conditional𝑤𝑞𝑝𝑣conditional~𝑣𝑤𝑞𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥2~𝑣𝑤𝑞𝑝subscript𝑦1conditionalsubscript𝑦2subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2\displaystyle p(q,w,x_{1},v,\tilde{v},x_{2},y_{1},y_{2})=p(q)p(x_{1},w|q)p(v,\tilde{v}|w,q)p(x_{2}|\tilde{v},w,q)p(y_{1},y_{2}|x_{1},x_{2}). (49)

Let ℛsp1​(p)subscriptℛsp1𝑝\mathcal{R}_{\text{sp1}}(p) denote the set of all non-negative rate pairs (R1,R2)subscript𝑅1subscript𝑅2(R_{1},R_{2}) such that

R1subscript𝑅1\displaystyle R_{1} ≤I​(W;Y1|Q),absent𝐼𝑊conditionalsubscript𝑌1𝑄\displaystyle\leq I(W;Y_{1}|Q), (50)

ℛsp1=⋃p​(⋅)∈𝒫1∗ℛsp1​(p).subscriptℛsp1subscript𝑝⋅subscriptsuperscript𝒫1subscriptℛsp1𝑝\mathcal{R}_{\text{sp1}}=\bigcup_{p(\cdot)\in\mathcal{P}^{*}_{1}}\mathcal{R}_{\text{sp1}}(p).
Corollary 1

The region ℛsp1subscriptℛsp1\mathcal{R}_{\text{sp1}} is an achievable rate region for the discrete memoryless IC-DMS, i.e., ℛsp1⊆ℛsuc⊆ℛsim⊆ℛ⊆𝒞subscriptℛsp1subscriptℛsucsubscriptℛsimℛ𝒞\mathcal{R}_{\text{sp1}}\subseteq\mathcal{R}_{\text{suc}}\subseteq\mathcal{R}_{\text{sim}}\subseteq\mathcal{R}\subseteq\mathcal{C}.

Proof:

Fixing the auxiliary random variable U𝑈U as a constant, we reduce (41) and (42) to (50) and (51), and the corollary follows immediately. ∎

Remark 3

We note that the region ℛsp1subscriptℛsp1\mathcal{R}_{\text{sp1}} is similar to the region ℛinsubscriptℛin\mathcal{R}_{\text{in}} reported in [3, Theorem 3.1]. It seems that the region ℛinsubscriptℛin\mathcal{R}_{\text{in}} is more general than the region ℛsp1subscriptℛsp1\mathcal{R}_{\text{sp1}} in the sense that fixing the auxiliary random variable U𝑈U in ℛinsubscriptℛin\mathcal{R}_{\text{in}} as a constant, one can obtain a region which is the same as ℛsp1subscriptℛsp1\mathcal{R}_{\text{sp1}}. Nevertheless, after examining the coding scheme used in [3, Theorem 3.1], one can find that there exists a one-one correspondence between codewords 𝐮​(w2)𝐮subscript𝑤2{\mathbf{u}}(w_{2}) and 𝐱2​(w2)subscript𝐱2subscript𝑤2{\mathbf{x}}_{2}(w_{2}), and both codewords are jointly generated and decoded, i.e., p​(u,x2)𝑝𝑢subscript𝑥2p(u,x_{2}) is used to generate two-letter codewords. Thus, one can introduce one auxiliary random variable W𝑊W such that there exists a one-one mapping between 𝒲𝒲\mathcal{W} and 𝒰×𝒳2𝒰subscript𝒳2\mathcal{U}\times\mathcal{X}_{2}, i.e., f:𝒰×𝒳2↔𝒲:𝑓𝒰subscript𝒳2↔𝒲f:\mathcal{U}\times\mathcal{X}_{2}\leftrightarrow\mathcal{W}, and thus W𝑊W has the probability mass distribution p​(w)=p​(f−1​(w))=p​(u,x2)𝑝𝑤𝑝superscript𝑓1𝑤𝑝𝑢subscript𝑥2p(w)=p(f^{-1}(w))=p(u,x_{2}). Replacing all (X2n​(w2),Un​(w2))superscriptsubscript𝑋2𝑛subscript𝑤2superscript𝑈𝑛subscript𝑤2(X_{2}^{n}(w_{2}),U^{n}(w_{2})) by Wn​(w2)superscript𝑊𝑛subscript𝑤2W^{n}(w_{2}) in the proof of [3, Theorem 3.1] will yield the same rate region. Equivalently speaking, for any input distribution achieving a rate region characterized by [3, Theorem 3.1], one can find a corresponding joint distribution in the form of (49) such that Corollary 1 yields exactly the same rate region. Therefore, two rate regions ℛsp1subscriptℛsp1\mathcal{R}_{\text{sp1}} and ℛinsubscriptℛin\mathcal{R}_{\text{in}} are identical.

Let 𝒫2∗subscriptsuperscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}^{*}_{2} denote the set of all joint probability distributions p​(⋅)𝑝⋅p(\cdot) that factor in the form of

p​(q,w,x1,u,x2,y1,y2)=p​(q)​p​(x1,w|q)​p​(u|q)​p​(x2|u,w,q)​p​(y1,y2|x1,x2).𝑝𝑞𝑤subscript𝑥1𝑢subscript𝑥2subscript𝑦1subscript𝑦2𝑝𝑞𝑝subscript𝑥1conditional𝑤𝑞𝑝conditional𝑢𝑞𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑥2𝑢𝑤𝑞𝑝subscript𝑦1conditionalsubscript𝑦2subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2\displaystyle p(q,w,x_{1},u,x_{2},y_{1},y_{2})=p(q)p(x_{1},w|q)p(u|q)p(x_{2}|u,w,q)p(y_{1},y_{2}|x_{1},x_{2}). (52)

Let ℛsp2​(p)subscriptℛsp2𝑝\mathcal{R}_{\text{sp2}}(p) denote the set of all non-negative rate pairs (R1,R2)subscript𝑅1subscript𝑅2(R_{1},R_{2}) such that

R1subscript𝑅1\displaystyle R_{1} ≤I​(W;Y1|U​Q),absent𝐼𝑊conditionalsubscript𝑌1𝑈𝑄\displaystyle\leq I(W;Y_{1}|UQ), (53)
R2subscript𝑅2\displaystyle R_{2} ≤min⁡{I​(U;Y1|Q),I​(U;Y2|Q)},absent𝐼𝑈conditionalsubscript𝑌1𝑄𝐼𝑈conditionalsubscript𝑌2𝑄\displaystyle\leq\min\{I(U;Y_{1}|Q),I(U;Y_{2}|Q)\}, (54)

for a fixed joint distribution p​(⋅)∈𝒫2∗𝑝⋅subscriptsuperscript𝒫2p(\cdot)\in\mathcal{P}^{*}_{2}. Define

The region ℛsp2subscriptℛsp2\mathcal{R}_{\text{sp2}} is an achievable rate region for the discrete memoryless IC-DMS, i.e., ℛsp2⊆ℛsuc⊆ℛsim⊆ℛ⊆𝒞subscriptℛsp2subscriptℛsucsubscriptℛsimℛ𝒞\mathcal{R}_{\text{sp2}}\subseteq\mathcal{R}_{\text{suc}}\subseteq\mathcal{R}_{\text{sim}}\subseteq\mathcal{R}\subseteq\mathcal{C}.

Proof:

The proof can be devised from the proof of Theorem 3 easily by fixing V𝑉V as a constant. ∎

V The Gaussian IC-DMS

In the preceding sections, we have derived several achievable rate regions for the discrete memoryless IC-DMS. We now extend these results to obtain corresponding achievable rate regions for the Gaussian IC-DMS (GIC-DMS).

V-A The Channel Model of the GIC-DMS

In general, with no loss of information-theoretic optimality, the GIC-DMS can be converted to the GIC-DMS in the standard form through invertible transformations [2, 11, 6]. We thus only consider the GIC-DMS in the standard form, which is represented as follows

Y1subscript𝑌1\displaystyle Y_{1} =X1+c21​X2+Z1,absentsubscript𝑋1subscript𝑐21subscript𝑋2subscript𝑍1\displaystyle=X_{1}+\sqrt{c_{21}}X_{2}+Z_{1},
Y2subscript𝑌2\displaystyle Y_{2} =X2+c12​X1+Z2,absentsubscript𝑋2subscript𝑐12subscript𝑋1subscript𝑍2\displaystyle=X_{2}+\sqrt{c_{12}}X_{1}+Z_{2},

where Zisubscript𝑍𝑖Z_{i}, i=1,2𝑖12i=1,2, is the additive white Gaussian noise with zero mean and unit variance, and c21subscript𝑐21\sqrt{c_{21}} and c12subscript𝑐12\sqrt{c_{12}} are the normalized link gains in the GIC-DMS depicted in Fig. 4.

Moreover, the transmitted codeword 𝐱i=(xi​1,…,xi​n)subscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖1…subscript𝑥𝑖𝑛{\mathbf{x}}_{i}=(x_{i1},\ldots,x_{in}), i=1,2𝑖12i=1,2, is subject to an average power constraint given by

1n​∑t=1n‖xi​t‖2≤Pi.1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑛superscriptnormsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑡2subscript𝑃𝑖\displaystyle\frac{1}{n}\sum_{t=1}^{n}\|{x_{it}}\|^{2}\leq P_{i}.

Since it has been shown in the maximum-entropy theorem in [8] that Gaussian input signals are optimal for Gaussian channels, we will consider Gaussian codewords Xinsubscriptsuperscript𝑋𝑛𝑖X^{n}_{i}, i=1,2𝑖12i=1,2.

V-B Achievable Rate Regions for the GIC-DMS

V-B1 Gaussian Extension of ℛℛ\mathcal{R}

We first extend ℛℛ\mathcal{R} to its Gaussian counterpart denoted by 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}. To obtain the rate region 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}, we map the random variables involved in the joint distribution (2) to the corresponding Gaussian random variables with the following customary constraints:

  1. P1)

    W𝑊W, distributed according to 𝒩​(0,1)𝒩01\mathcal{N}(0,1),

  2. P2)

    X1=P1​Wsubscript𝑋1subscript𝑃1𝑊X_{1}=\sqrt{P_{1}}W,

  3. P3)

    U~~𝑈\tilde{U}, distributed according to 𝒩​(0,α​β​P2)𝒩0𝛼𝛽subscript𝑃2\mathcal{N}(0,\alpha\beta P_{2}),

  4. P4)

    V~~𝑉\tilde{V}, distributed according to 𝒩​(0,α​β¯​P2)𝒩0𝛼¯𝛽subscript𝑃2\mathcal{N}(0,\alpha\bar{\beta}P_{2}),

  5. P5)

    U𝑈U = U~+λ1​W~𝑈subscript𝜆1𝑊\tilde{U}+\lambda_{1}W,

  6. P6)

    V𝑉V = V~+λ2​W~𝑉subscript𝜆2𝑊\tilde{V}+\lambda_{2}W,

  7. P7)

    X2=U~+V~+α¯​P2​Wsubscript𝑋2~𝑈~𝑉¯𝛼subscript𝑃2𝑊X_{2}=\tilde{U}+\tilde{V}+\sqrt{\bar{\alpha}P_{2}}W,

where α,β∈[0,1]𝛼𝛽01\alpha,\beta\in[0,1], α+α¯=1𝛼¯𝛼1\alpha+\bar{\alpha}=1, β+β¯=1𝛽¯𝛽1\beta+\bar{\beta}=1, λ1,λ2∈[0,+∞)subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆20\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2}\in[0,+\infty), and W𝑊W, U~~𝑈\tilde{U} and V~~𝑉\tilde{V} are mutually independent. The input-output relationship of the GIC-DMS can be described by

Y1subscript𝑌1\displaystyle Y_{1} =(P1+c21​α¯​P2)​W+c21​U~+c21​V~+Z1,absentsubscript𝑃1subscript𝑐21¯𝛼subscript𝑃2𝑊subscript𝑐21~𝑈subscript𝑐21~𝑉subscript𝑍1\displaystyle=\left(\sqrt{P_{1}}+\sqrt{c_{21}\bar{\alpha}P_{2}}\right)W+\sqrt{c_{21}}\tilde{U}+\sqrt{c_{21}}\tilde{V}+Z_{1}, (55)
Y2subscript𝑌2\displaystyle Y_{2} =U~+V~+(α¯​P2+c12​P1)​W+Z2.absent~𝑈~𝑉¯𝛼subscript𝑃2subscript𝑐12subscript𝑃1𝑊subscript𝑍2\displaystyle=\tilde{U}+\tilde{V}+\left(\sqrt{\bar{\alpha}P_{2}}+\sqrt{c_{12}P_{1}}\right)W+Z_{2}. (56)

To simplify the derivations, we fix the time-sharing random variable Q𝑄Q as a constant. The issue of how this time-sharing random variable affects the achievable rate region is well addressed in [13]. In the Gaussian case, the respective mutual information terms in (3) – (9) need be evaluated with respect to the mappings defined by P1–P7. Since the computation procedure to obtain 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} and the resulting description of 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} are fairly lengthy, we relegate them (Theorem 5) to the Appendix.

V-B2 Gaussian Extension of ℛsucsubscriptℛsuc\mathcal{R}_{\text{suc}}

For illustration and comparison purpose, we next show how to obtain the Gaussian counterpart of ℛsucsubscriptℛsuc\mathcal{R}_{\text{suc}} in details. Following the first step in the previous derivation, we also map the random variables involved in (30) to the Gaussian ones with the following constraints:

  1. M1)

    W𝑊W, distributed according to 𝒩​(0,1)𝒩01\mathcal{N}(0,1),

  2. M2)

    X1=P1​Wsubscript𝑋1subscript𝑃1𝑊X_{1}=\sqrt{P_{1}}W,

  3. M3)

    U𝑈U, distributed according to 𝒩​(0,α​β​P2)𝒩0𝛼𝛽subscript𝑃2\mathcal{N}(0,\alpha\beta P_{2}),

  4. M4)

    V~~𝑉\tilde{V}, distributed according to 𝒩​(0,α​β¯​P2)𝒩0𝛼¯𝛽subscript𝑃2\mathcal{N}(0,\alpha\bar{\beta}P_{2}),

  5. M5)

    V𝑉V = V~+λ​W~𝑉𝜆𝑊\tilde{V}+\lambda W,

  6. M6)

    X2=U+V~+α¯​P2​Wsubscript𝑋2𝑈~𝑉¯𝛼subscript𝑃2𝑊X_{2}=U+\tilde{V}+\sqrt{\bar{\alpha}P_{2}}W,

where α,β∈[0,1]𝛼𝛽01\alpha,\beta\in[0,1], α+α¯=1𝛼¯𝛼1\alpha+\bar{\alpha}=1, β+β¯=1𝛽¯𝛽1\beta+\bar{\beta}=1, λ∈[0,+∞)𝜆0\lambda\in[0,+\infty), and W𝑊W, U𝑈U and V~~𝑉\tilde{V} are mutually independent. Using the mappings defined by M1–M6, we express the input-output relationship for the GIC-DMS as:

Y1subscript𝑌1\displaystyle Y_{1} =(P1+c21​α¯​P2)​W+c21​U+c21​V~+Z1,absentsubscript𝑃1subscript𝑐21¯𝛼subscript𝑃2𝑊subscript𝑐21𝑈subscript𝑐21~𝑉subscript𝑍1\displaystyle=\left(\sqrt{P_{1}}+\sqrt{c_{21}\bar{\alpha}P_{2}}\right)W+\sqrt{c_{21}}U+\sqrt{c_{21}}\tilde{V}+Z_{1}, (57)
Y2subscript𝑌2\displaystyle Y_{2} =U+V~+(α¯​P2+c12​P1)​W+Z2.absent𝑈~𝑉¯𝛼subscript𝑃2subscript𝑐12subscript𝑃1𝑊subscript𝑍2\displaystyle=U+\tilde{V}+\left(\sqrt{\bar{\alpha}P_{2}}+\sqrt{c_{12}P_{1}}\right)W+Z_{2}. (58)

Let 𝒢suc​(α,β)subscript𝒢suc𝛼𝛽\mathcal{G}_{\text{suc}}(\alpha,\beta) denote the set of all the non-negative rate pairs (R1,R2)subscript𝑅1subscript𝑅2(R_{1},R_{2}) such that

R1≤subscript𝑅1absent\displaystyle R_{1}\leq 12​log2⁡(1+(P1+c21​α¯​P2)2c21​α​β¯​P2+1),12subscript21superscriptsubscript𝑃1subscript𝑐21¯𝛼subscript𝑃22subscript𝑐21𝛼¯𝛽subscript𝑃21\displaystyle\frac{1}{2}\log_{2}\left(1+\frac{\left(\sqrt{P_{1}}+\sqrt{c_{21}\bar{\alpha}P_{2}}\right)^{2}}{c_{21}\alpha\bar{\beta}P_{2}+1}\right), (59)
R2≤subscript𝑅2absent\displaystyle R_{2}\leq 12log2(1+αβ¯P2)+min{12log2(1+c21​α​β​P2(P1+c21​α¯​P2)2+c21​α​β¯​P2+1),\displaystyle\frac{1}{2}\log_{2}(1+\alpha\bar{\beta}P_{2})+\min\Bigg{\{}\frac{1}{2}\log_{2}\left(1+\frac{c_{21}\alpha\beta P_{2}}{\left(\sqrt{P_{1}}+\sqrt{c_{21}\bar{\alpha}P_{2}}\right)^{2}+c_{21}\alpha\bar{\beta}P_{2}+1}\right),
12log2(1+α​β​P2α​β¯​P2+(α¯​P2+c12​P1)2+1)}.\displaystyle\qquad\qquad\qquad\quad\qquad\qquad\frac{1}{2}\log_{2}\left(1+\frac{\alpha\beta P_{2}}{\alpha\bar{\beta}P_{2}+\left(\sqrt{\bar{\alpha}P_{2}}+\sqrt{c_{12}P_{1}}\right)^{2}+1}\right)\Bigg{\}}. (60)

Define

𝒢suc=⋃α,β∈[0,1]𝒢suc​(α,β).subscript𝒢sucsubscript𝛼𝛽01subscript𝒢suc𝛼𝛽\mathcal{G}_{\text{suc}}=\bigcup_{\alpha,\beta\in[0,1]}\mathcal{G}_{\text{suc}}(\alpha,\beta).
Theorem 4

The region 𝒢sucsubscript𝒢suc\mathcal{G}_{\text{suc}} is an achievable rate region for the GIC-DMS in the standard form.

Proof:

It suffices to prove that 𝒢suc​(α,β)subscript𝒢suc𝛼𝛽\mathcal{G}_{\text{suc}}(\alpha,\beta) is achievable for any given α,β∈[0,1]𝛼𝛽01\alpha,\beta\in[0,1]. Since 𝒢sucsubscript𝒢suc\mathcal{G}_{\text{suc}} is extended from ℛsucsubscriptℛsuc\mathcal{R}_{\text{suc}}, we need compute the mutual information terms in (41) and (42). The righthand side of (59) can be readily obtained through a straightforward computation of I​(W;Y1|U​Q)𝐼𝑊conditionalsubscript𝑌1𝑈𝑄I(W;Y_{1}|UQ) in (41). Recall that Q𝑄Q is a constant. It is also fairly straightforward to obtain the two terms within the minimum operator in (60) through computing I​(U;Y1|Q)𝐼𝑈conditionalsubscript𝑌1𝑄I(U;Y_{1}|Q) and I​(U;Y2|Q)𝐼𝑈conditionalsubscript𝑌2𝑄I(U;Y_{2}|Q) in (42). We next evaluate the only remaining term I​(V;Y2|U​Q)−I​(V;W|Q)𝐼𝑉conditionalsubscript𝑌2𝑈𝑄𝐼𝑉conditional𝑊𝑄I(V;Y_{2}|UQ)-I(V;W|Q) for a constant Q𝑄Q. (62)

It is easy to find that when

the term I​(V;Y|U)−I​(V;W)𝐼𝑉conditional𝑌𝑈𝐼𝑉𝑊I(V;Y|U)-I(V;W) is maximized, and the maximum value is

This is in parallel with the result in [12].

Therefore, the rate region 𝒢suc​(α,β)subscript𝒢suc𝛼𝛽\mathcal{G}_{\text{suc}}(\alpha,\beta) is achievable for any pair α,β∈[0,1]𝛼𝛽01\alpha,\beta\in[0,1], and the theorem follows. ∎

In the following, we obtain two corollaries by setting β=0𝛽0\beta=0 and β=1𝛽1\beta=1 in Theorem 4, respectively.

Corollary 3

over all α∈[0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1].

Remark 4

Corollaries 3 and 4 correspond the Gaussian extensions of Corollaries 1 and 2 respectively. Particularly, the rate region depicted by Corollary 3 is the same as the rate regions given in [2, Theorem 4.1] and [3, Theorem 3.5]. It has been proven in both [2] and [3] that the rate region 𝒢sp1subscript𝒢sp1\mathcal{G}_{\text{sp1}} is indeed the capacity region for the GIC-DMS in the low-interference-gain regime, i.e., c21≤1subscript𝑐211c_{21}\leq 1.

In addition, the set of achievable rate pairs given in [2, Lemma 4.2] is contained in the region 𝒢sp2subscript𝒢sp2\mathcal{G}_{\text{sp2}} as a subset.

V-C Numerical Examples

We next provide several numerical examples to illustrate improvements of our achievable rate regions over the previously known results in [1, 2, 3]. Denote the achievable rate regions obtained in [1, Theorem 1] and [1, Corollary2] by 𝒢dmt1subscript𝒢dmt1\mathcal{G}_{\text{dmt1}} and 𝒢dmt2subscript𝒢dmt2\mathcal{G}_{\text{dmt2}}, respectively.

V-C1 Comparing with Rate Regions in [1]

Fig. 5 compares the rate regions 𝒢dmt1subscript𝒢dmt1\mathcal{G}_{\text{dmt1}}, 𝒢dmt2subscript𝒢dmt2\mathcal{G}_{\text{dmt2}}, and 𝒢sp1subscript𝒢sp1\mathcal{G}_{\text{sp1}} for an extreme case in which receiver 2 does not experience any interference from sender 1, i.e., c12=0subscript𝑐120c_{12}=0. As can be seen from Fig. 5, the rate region 𝒢sp1subscript𝒢sp1\mathcal{G}_{\text{sp1}} strictly includes 𝒢dmt1subscript𝒢dmt1\mathcal{G}_{\text{dmt1}}, as well as 𝒢dmt2subscript𝒢dmt2\mathcal{G}_{\text{dmt2}} obtained through time-sharing between 𝒢dmt1subscript𝒢dmt1\mathcal{G}_{\text{dmt1}} and a fully-cooperative rate point. The coding scheme used to establish 𝒢dmt1subscript𝒢dmt1\mathcal{G}_{\text{dmt1}} incurs certain rate loss due to the fact that sender 2 does not use its power to help the sender 1’s transmissions even though it has complete and non-causal knowledge about the message being transmitted by sender 1. In contrast, our proposed coding scheme allows sender 2 to use superposition coding to help sender 1, and thus yields an improved rate region.

In Fig. 6, we consider another case in which the transmit power of sender 1 is set to zero and c21≤1subscript𝑐211c_{21}\leq 1. From the figure, we observe that the rate region 𝒢dmt2subscript𝒢dmt2\mathcal{G}_{\text{dmt2}} is strictly smaller than 𝒢sp1subscript𝒢sp1\mathcal{G}_{\text{sp1}}. Note that in this case, the GIC-DMS becomes a Gaussian degraded broadcast channel. According to [8], the optimal coding scheme for this case is: sender 2 uses a portion of its power to transmit the codeword conveying w1subscript𝑤1w_{1}, and uses the remaining power to transmit the codeword conveying w2subscript𝑤2w_{2}, which is encoded by using the dirty-paper coding [14]. It is easy to verify that this scheme is a special case of the coding scheme developed in Theorem 1.

V-C2 Comparing with Rate Regions in [2, 3]

As mentioned earlier, the rate region 𝒢sp1subscript𝒢sp1\mathcal{G}_{\text{sp1}}, a subregion of 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G}, is the same as the one given in [2, Theorem 4.1] and the one given in [3, Theorem 3.5], which is indeed the capacity region for GIC-DMS in the low-interference-gain regime. In Figs. 7 and 8, we compare 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} with 𝒢sp1subscript𝒢sp1\mathcal{G}_{\text{sp1}} and 𝒢sp2subscript𝒢sp2\mathcal{G}_{\text{sp2}} in the high-interference-gain regime, i.e., c21>1subscript𝑐211c_{21}>1. As can be seen from the figures, the rate region 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} strictly includes both 𝒢sp1subscript𝒢sp1\mathcal{G}_{\text{sp1}} and 𝒢sp2subscript𝒢sp2\mathcal{G}_{\text{sp2}} in this case. Comparing Fig. 7 with Fig. 8, we observe that the improvement of the rate region 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} over 𝒢sp1subscript𝒢sp1\mathcal{G}_{\text{sp1}} becomes more pronounced as the link gain c21subscript𝑐21c_{21} increases. The improvement is mainly because our coding scheme allows receiver 1 to decode partial information from sender 2, and thus reduces the effective interference experienced by receiver 1. In addition, it can be seen from the figures that in the high-interference-gain regime, 𝒢sp1subscript𝒢sp1\mathcal{G}_{\text{sp1}} is not convex and thus is only suboptimal.

VI Conclusions

In this paper, we have investigated the IC-DMS from an information theoretic perspective. We have developed a coding scheme that combines the advantages of cooperative coding, collaborative coding and Gel’fand-Pinsker coding. With the coding scheme, we have derived a new achievable rate region for such a channel, which not only includes existing results as special cases, but also exceeds them in the high-interference-gain regime. However, we are not able to establish a converse for the derived achievable rate region, because the achievable result is closely related to the achievable results for the interference channel and the broadcast channel, for which there is no converse available in general.

The mutual information terms in (3)–(9) are then computed as:

I1=ha+hb−hc,subscript𝐼1subscriptℎ𝑎subscriptℎ𝑏subscriptℎ𝑐\displaystyle I_{1}=h_{a}+h_{b}-h_{c},

Let 𝒢​(α,β,λ1,λ2)𝒢𝛼𝛽subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆2\mathcal{G}(\alpha,\beta,\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2}) denote the set of all rate pairs (R1,R2)subscript𝑅1subscript𝑅2(R_{1},R_{2}) such that the following inequalities are satisfied:

for given α,β∈[0,1]𝛼𝛽01\alpha,\beta\in[0,1] and λ1,λ2∈[0,+∞)subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆20\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2}\in[0,+\infty). Note that (65)–(71) are directly extended from (3)–(9).

Theorem 5

The rate region 𝒢𝒢\mathcal{G} is achievable for the GIC-DMS in the standard form with

𝒢=⋃α,β∈[0,1];λ1,λ2∈[0,+∞)𝒢​(α,β,λ1,λ2).𝒢subscriptformulae-sequence𝛼𝛽01subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆20𝒢𝛼𝛽subscript𝜆1subscript𝜆2\displaystyle\mathcal{G}=\bigcup_{\alpha,\beta\in[0,1];\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2}\in[0,+\infty)}\mathcal{G}(\alpha,\beta,\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2}).
